0.user_question: Karan borrowed $3,650 for five months at an interest rate of 10%. She has to pay an equal amount every month. How much does she have to pay per month?

1.subquestion: How much interest will be charged over five months if no repayments are made during those period?

subanswer.text: With a loan of $3,650, ten percent annual interest would add up to ($3,650 x 0.10) or $365 annually. Over five months (which is approximately one quarter), the charge would therefore approximate to about 365/4=$91.25 . Hence, Interest paid equals Principal Amount times Rate(percentage)/time=($3650*10%)*1/4=$91.25 , This should not exceed principal but just under it because usually banks give you your full deposit back when closing loans earlier unless penalty applies. Answer :$91.25 Approximately; However remember actual calculations may slightly differ based upon bank policies etc.. Thus always confirm directly wiht financial institution regarding exact figures...or consider using online calculators available freely via internet searches eg Banks websites! ;-)
